intro: Ptilotus schwartzii var. schwartzii, commonly known as the pink ghost flower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Australia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its striking, pink to purple, velvety bracts that resemble ghostly shapes. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often hidden within the bracts. It is adapted to survive in dry, sandy soils and can thrive in full sun. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in arid gardens for ornamental purposes.
